__data__.text: Picardo was born in Jerez de la Frontera, Spain, in 1919 to Alvaro Picardo de Celis and a mother from the Castellón family. He had four brothers, but one passed away in infancy. His father died when he was ten, leading his family to relocate to Madrid. There, he started high school at the Instituto de Bachillerato Cervantes.

Picardo, born in 1919, moved to Madrid after his father's death and began high school at the Instituto de Bachillerato Cervantes. He first aimed to join the navy, but the military academies' closure during the Second Spanish Republic hindered him. He then pursued law studies, which were cut short by the Spanish Civil War's outbreak in July 1936 when he was 17. Eventually, he found his path in architecture.

Upon turning 17, Picardo, in an effort to stay in Madrid as the Spanish Civil War broke out, started working in the architecture studio of Luis Moya Blanco, who was 15 years older and a professor at the Higher Technical School of Architecture of Madrid. Moya Blanco, recognizing Picardo's talents, advised him to switch from law to architecture. Due to the Civil War and subsequent dictatorship, Spain experienced a decrease in the number of architects.

After the Spanish Civil War and Franco's dictatorship, many architects who had thrived during the Republic either perished in the war, went into exile, or were professionally disqualified, leading to a decrease in the number of architects. In response, the Dirección General de Aquitectura was established by Franco's regime to oversee architecture in Spain and support its national reconstruction, with numerous architects having to work under its authority.

Following the Spanish Civil War and Franco's dictatorship, the Dirección General de Aquitectura was established to regulate architecture, causing many architects to work under its supervision. In this context, Picardo started his studies at the Escuela Técnica Superior de Arquitectura de Madrid in 1945, where his painting and drawing skills, especially his perspective mastery, gained recognition from architects. They even commissioned murals from him and hired him for graphic representations and perspectives of their plans while he was still a student.

After the Spanish Civil War, Picardo started his architectural studies in 1945 and showcased exceptional painting and drawing skills, leading to mural commissions and graphic work from architects. At 20, he created his first professional mural at Cine Fígaro (Figaro Cinema) through mentor Luis Moya Blanco. Murals became his primary income source during his formative years, and he contributed illustrations and cover designs to architectural magazines Revista Nacional de Arquitectura and Boletín de la Dirección General de Arquitectura while studying.

Following the Spanish Civil War, Picardo pursued architectural studies, exhibiting remarkable painting and drawing abilities. His artistic talent led to mural commissions and graphic work from architects during his formative years. He produced his first professional mural at Cine Fígaro at the age of 20, mentored by Luis Moya Blanco. Murals became his primary income source, and he contributed illustrations and cover designs to architectural magazines, showcasing growing sophistication, complexity, and high-quality work. Notably, his post-student illustrations featured Madrid in the 1950s and 1960s, the Spanish protectorate in Morocco, and the Canary Islands. Additionally, he developed a keen interest in historic architecture preservation and restoration. Picardo finalized his education with extensive travels to study buildings in Spain and abroad.

After completing his architectural studies and gaining recognition through mural commissions and graphic work, Picardo traveled extensively in Spain and abroad to examine buildings, furthering his passion for historical and vernacular architecture. Upon qualifying as an architect in 1951, he began working with the renowned architect and historian Fernando Chueca Goitia on architectural preservation and restoration projects, demonstrating his early commitment to this field.

Upon beginning his architecture career, Picardo collaborated with the esteemed architect and historian Fernando Chueca Goitia, known for his extensive research into enduring features of Spanish architecture that remained consistent despite shifts in politics and religion. Picardo's dedication to architectural preservation was showcased when he became one of the 24 signatories of the "Manifiesto de la Alhambra" in 1952, a significant text in the historiography of 20th-century Spanish architecture, which Chueca played a major role in initiating.

In the beginning of his architectural career, Picardo worked with the renowned architect and historian, Fernando Chueca Goitia, who focused on enduring aspects of Spanish architecture. A pivotal moment in Picardo's career was becoming a signatory of the "Manifiesto de la Alhambra" in 1952, a document co-initiated by Chueca, which aimed to create a Spanish style of modern architecture inspired by the Alhambra in Granada, Andalucía. This inspiration significantly shaped Picardo's work, particularly in his Paradores projects. During the 1950s, Picardo actively pursued his architectural goals by participating in competitions and publishing designs for uncommissioned buildings.

In 1951, Picardo, along with Carlos de Miguel, designed a Fishermen's Brotherhood center in Altea, which gained significant attention but unfortunately remained unconstructed. Following this, Picardo embarked on designing a small hotel as a solo project, to be situated on the Costa del Sol in Andalucía, an endeavor influenced by his work with Chueca and the Alhambra inspiration.

In the early 1950s, Picardo undertook a solo hotel design project in Costa del Sol, inspired by his collaboration with Chueca and the Alhambra. He referred to this hotel as a "modest inn," characterized by a simple and appealing design. Concurrently, Picardo participated in two competitions for the Treasury Delegation in Gerona and Las Palmas, placing second in both to architect Carlos Sobrini, who had been his college contemporary.

In the 1950s, Picardo, inspired by his past collaborations, designed a modest hotel in Costa del Sol and entered two competitions with Carlos Sobrini, coming in second. Later, in 1958, Picardo and his brother Carlos co-designed an apartment building near Madrid's Plaza de Las Ventas for middle-class families. In the early 1960s, Picardo built traditional houses in the Andalucían style on the Costa del Sol and in Jerez, while also constructing modern apartment blocks for Urbis in Madrid. Throughout this period, Picardo often faced competition with Carlos Sobrini, sometimes resulting in defeat.

During the 1960s, Picardo shifted his focus to designing modernist apartment buildings for Urbis in Madrid, leaving behind his competition with Carlos Sobrini. He also began working on commissions for the Spanish Ministerio de Información y Turismo, which set the stage for his significant contributions to the state-owned luxury hotel network, Paradores de Turismo de España. Early in his career, Picardo was already recognized for his exceptional drafting skills, creating detailed sketches, perspectives, and plans that highlighted his abilities.

In the 1960s, Picardo transitioned to designing contemporary apartment complexes for Urbis in Madrid, moving away from his rivalry with Carlos Sobrini. He also started receiving commissions from the Spanish Ministerio de Información y Turismo, which led to his major contributions to the government-owned luxury hotel chain, Paradores de Turismo de España. Continuing from his earlier years, Picardo gained recognition for his exceptional drafting skills, producing intricate sketches, perspectives, and plans. Moreover, he kept receiving decorative mural painting projects, showcasing his color and technique expertise in places like the Hotel de Los Cisnes in Jerez and various establishments in Madrid, such as Bar Jerez, Hotel Plaza, and the Engineers' Residence of the National Institute of Colonization.

In the 1950s and 1960s, Picardo expanded his work beyond his rivalry with Carlos Sobrini, gaining recognition for his detailed sketches, perspectives, and plans in various projects. He contributed to the Exposición de Regiones Devastadas, the Instituto de Óptica "Daza de Valdés," and the sales area of the Garaje Villamagna. In 1953, he completed extensive decorative mural paintings, including two large curved panoramic views of Madrid and Cádiz, at the Restaurante Commodore in Madrid. These projects highlighted his color and technique expertise, further establishing his reputation.

During the 1950s and 1960s, Picardo's work evolved as he gained recognition for his intricate sketches, perspectives, and plans in various projects. He excelled in mural painting, completing two large murals depicting Madrid and Cádiz, which showcased his color and technique mastery, enhancing his reputation. Additionally, his architectural drawings, created in collaboration with Leopoldo Torres Balbás for the textbook Arquitectura Popular Española, were highly regarded. These drawings resulted from their travels throughout Spain, meticulously documenting vernacular architectural elements. This further established Picardo's prowess as a draftsman in the field of Spanish monumental and historic architecture.

In the 1950s-1960s, Picardo's work garnered recognition for detailed sketches and plans, particularly in mural painting, such as his celebrated Madrid and Cádiz murals. His architectural drawings with Leopoldo Torres Balbás also earned praise. In 1959, Picardo received a unique commission from Loewe, a Spanish fashion brand, to design a pack of playing cards. He imaginatively depicted the kings as historical figures, like Charlemagne, Goliath, Julius Caesar, and Alexander the Great, which was considered "magnificent" by leading Spanish restoration architect Luis Menéndez-Pidal y Álvarez. These accomplishments solidified Picardo's reputation as a master draftsman in Spanish architecture and advertising design.

During the 1950s-1960s, Picardo gained fame for his detailed sketches and plans, including murals like the celebrated Madrid and Cádiz ones, and architectural drawings with Leopoldo Torres Balbás. His reputation was further enhanced in 1959 when he designed a pack of playing cards for Loewe, featuring kings as historical figures, which was highly praised by Luis Menéndez-Pidal y Álvarez. Additionally, Picardo created a set of wooden chess pieces with tall, slender, conical shapes and intricate indications of the pieces' types. These games designs were produced in color by Naipes Heraclio Fournier and are now highly sought after by collectors. These accomplishments cemented Picardo's status as a master draftsman in Spanish architecture and advertising design.

In the early 1960s, Picardo received recognition from the Dirección General de Arquitectura (DGA) for his numerous illustrations in the DGA's Boletín since his student days. The DGA published a book, "Dibujos de José Luis Picardo," featuring over 60 of his drawings, including illustrations and humorous cartoons. The foreword likened Picardo's work to that of renowned illustrators such as Saul Steinberg, Osbert Lancaster, and Hugh Casson. This recognition solidified Picardo's standing as a distinguished illustrator in Spain.

The book showcasing Picardo's illustrations is hard to find in Spain and elsewhere, although second-hand copies exist. Picardo extensively contributed to Paradores de Turismo, a state-run hotel chain, from the early 1960s until 1985, having previously done minor work for the Ministerio de Información y Turismo that oversaw the hotel network. This summary conveys the rarity of the book and Picardo's long-term commitment to Paradores de Turismo.

The Spanish Ministry of Information and Tourism, and its predecessors, dedicated over three decades to restoring and transforming old, often dilapidated, historic structures like castles and convents into upscale hotels, creating a unique hospitality experience that surpassed traditional hotel offerings. This information highlights the Ministry's long-term investment in cultural preservation and tourism development, complementing Picardo's extensive involvement with Paradores de Turismo.

In the 1960s, with the rise of Spanish tourism, the Ministry of Information and Tourism significantly expanded its Parador program, from 40 to 83 establishments. Picardo, known for his historical restoration expertise and interest in traditional architecture, was tapped by the Ministry to lead many of these projects. His work often involved restoring old, monumental buildings or creating new structures in the style of ruined monuments. This information underscores the Ministry's continued commitment to cultural preservation and tourism growth, further linking Picardo's work with Paradores de Turismo.

During the 1960s Spanish tourism boom, the Ministry of Information and Tourism, committed to cultural preservation and tourism growth, hired Picardo for Parador projects. Picardo, known for his expertise in historical restoration and traditional architecture, often combined old monumental structures with modern hotel arrangements, preserving and enhancing their ancient appearance while incorporating luxurious, detailed designs for door furniture and landscapes, as evidenced by his surviving drawings and sketches showcasing his spatial vision and mastery of perspective. These projects emphasize the connection between Picardo's work and Paradores de Turismo.

During his two-decade tenure with the Paradores de Turismo, Picardo undertook eleven significant restoration projects of historical buildings, often adding modern touches while preserving their original appearance. He also built new structures that complemented the old ones or were constructed on their remains. Picardo's work demonstrates his mastery of perspective and spatial vision, as well as his meticulous skill. Additionally, he was involved in other Parador projects that did not come to fruition. This summary captures Picardo's contributions to Paradores de Turismo and his expertise in historical restoration and traditional architecture.

Picardo's involvement extended to various unrealized Parador projects, showcasing his versatile skills. His successful restoration projects significantly influenced Spanish and Portuguese architects in the state-run hotel chains. His work for Paradores de Turismo is highly praised by professionals and guests alike, who appreciate the historical ambiance and romantic allure of his designs, as exemplified by the Parador de Guadalupe: Zurbarán. This summary emphasizes Picardo's influence and the admiration for his contributions to Paradores de Turismo.

Picardo was tasked with converting two 14th-century buildings, including the Hospital de San Juan Bautista, into the first Parador project in Guadalupe, Cáceres, demonstrating his early involvement and impact on the organization's development.

Picardo's second assignment was to renovate the Colegio de Infantes, also known as the Colegio de Gramática, a 16th-century structure near the significant Monastery of Santa María de Guadalupe. This monastery was a central landmark in the village. The purpose of the Colegio was to provide education to boys. This project, like the Hospital de San Juan Bautista, contributed to the early stages of the Parador project in Guadalupe, Cáceres.

In the context of the previous text, the Colegio de Infantes was incorporated into the Catálogo de Monumentos Nacionales when Guadalupe was named a nationally significant historic-artistic monument. This college, also known as the Colegio de Gramática, was in disrepair and being used for simple housing and workshops. As part of the early stages of the Parador project in Guadalupe, Cáceres, Picardo's task was to maintain the existing structures, such as a notable Mudéjar staircase, and restore the buildings to their original style during the construction of a hotel.

In the Parador project, Picardo partially demolished and rebuilt the dilapidated structures of the Colegio de Infantes, preserving its original Mudéjar design using traditional techniques. He established the hotel's main hospitality area inside the Colegio, extending the southern side of the cloister to accommodate a dining room and guest rooms with terraces overlooking the garden. The cloister's lower arches were kept open, while the upper ones were enclosed with glass and wooden latticework.

In the Parador project, Picardo preserved the wooden framework, coffered ceilings, and clay tile flooring in the renovated areas of the Colegio. The Hospital de San Juan Bautista was converted into the hotel's kitchens, service areas, laundry, staff quarters, and parking. Additionally, a spacious breakfast room was constructed on the hospital building's first floor facing the street. The original architectural elements were maintained during these transformations.

In the Parador project, Picardo added a big breakfast room on the ground floor of the hospital building, facing the street. He ensured proper ventilation for all areas by installing chimneys adorned with Arabic tiles, whitewashed uprights, and starry latticework, topped with glazed ceramic tiles in white, blue, and green. Picardo also designed most of the furniture and interior decoration, incorporating historical explanatory tiles by ceramicist Juan Manuel Arroyo Ruiz de Luna, which he personally signed. Throughout these changes, original architectural features were preserved.

Over twenty years, Picardo frequently collaborated with ceramicist Juan Manuel Arroyo Ruiz Luna in the Parador projects, making Arroyo's work a signature element of Picardo's designs. The restoration of Guadalupe began in November 1963 and opened as a hotel with twenty double rooms in December 1965. Picardo returned in 1981 to add a new wing of guest rooms, ensuring their style remained consistent with the original building while offering scenic views of the monastery and surrounding mountains. Throughout these projects, Picardo maintained existing architectural features.

In the Parador projects, Picardo and ceramicist Juan Manuel Arroyo Ruiz Luna collaborated for over two decades, with Arroyo's work being a prominent feature in Picardo's designs. The restoration of Guadalupe, which began in 1963 and opened as a hotel in 1965, was expanded in 1981 with a new wing, designed by Picardo, that added 21 more guest rooms, increasing the total to 41. However, due to being added later, access to the new wing was challenging, involving numerous staircases and lifts. During this time, Picardo also worked on a separate project, designing and constructing a Parador at Castillo de Santa Catalina in Jaén, Andalucía. Throughout these projects, Picardo preserved the existing architectural elements.

The Castillo de Santa Catalina, where Picardo worked on a Parador project, is a 13th-century castle constructed on a Moorish fortress site. It had suffered damage in past wars and was abandoned by the time Picardo started the restoration in 1963, for which he prepared draft plans by late summer that year. The castle, located on a steep hill 800 meters above the city, offers panoramic views.

In the Castillo de Santa Catalina project, Picardo decided to construct a hostería, focusing on providing a refreshing experience rather than accommodation. Instead of repurposing the castle building, he chose to build on the site of the old barracks and stables, allowing for large windows to take advantage of the panoramic views, which wasn't possible if built within the castle itself. The hostería included a dining room, lounge, service areas, and guest rooms, making use of the elongated hilltop location.

In the Castillo de Santa Catalina project, Picardo designed the new hostería based on the layout and dimensions of the old castle, incorporating elements from the castle's surviving interior designs discovered during his research. Construction began in 1963, and the hostería, featuring 7 double guest rooms with fireplaces and wooden balconies, was opened to guests on 11 September 1965. The building's design would be replicated in Picardo's subsequent Parador projects.

In the Castillo de Santa Catalina project, Picardo created a mezzanine floor with a cafeteria, bar, and outdoor terrace, and placed the reception, lounge, restaurant, service areas, single rooms for drivers, and a mechanical workshop on the ground floor. The building's exterior was cladded with materials such as stone, brick, timber, and iron, concealing the 20th-century concrete, steel, block, and cement structure, giving the impression that the cladding formed the whole construction. This design approach was also used in Picardo's Parador projects, including the one in Jaén, which served as a tribute to the neighboring castle.

In the Castillo de Santa Catalina project, Picardo used a design approach that involved cladding the building's exterior and certain interior elements with traditional materials to create a historical appearance, while concealing modern structures. For instance, the 20-meter-high vault of the lounge, which seems to be made of brick, hides a supporting skeleton of modern materials. Similarly, the six large stone arches in the dining room, which give the impression of supporting the ceiling and roof, conceal the room's steel frame. Later, in 1969, Picardo added service rooms to the south wall. This approach was also employed in Picardo's Parador projects, such as the one in Jaén, as a tribute to nearby historical structures.

In 1969, Picardo expanded the Castillo de Santa Catalina by constructing service rooms on the south wall, transforming the old service area into additional guest rooms. Subsequently, due to heavy rain and unstable ground, the castle and hostería experienced landslips, requiring Picardo to reinforce the building multiple times between the late 1960s and early 1970s. In 1973, Picardo undertook another extension project, maintaining the same historical design style. This approach was similarly applied in his Parador projects, such as the one in Jaén, as a homage to nearby historical structures.

In 1973, Picardo constructed a new extension on the west side of the initial building, connected by a tower, allowing for a difference in heights. This addition included 24 more guest rooms, increasing the total to 43. However, due to land constraints and building height limits, the extension stretched the building, resulting in lengthy corridors and distances between rooms and common areas. This design approach mirrored his style in other projects, such as the Parador in Jaén, as a tribute to nearby historical architecture.

Upon the completion of Picardo's extension in 1973, the building officially became a Parador, opening with a formal inauguration in 1978. In keeping with the medieval theme, Picardo designed the interior, creating furniture, decorations, and tile patterns that reflected the building's historical architecture. He even incorporated coats of arms from demolished buildings into both the interior and exterior design elements.

Upon the completion of Picardo's extension in 1973, the building was transformed into a Parador, officially opening in 1978. Picardo, who designed the interior, incorporated coats of arms from demolished buildings into both the interior and exterior design elements. He also used hand-painted ceramic tiles, created by Juan Manuel Arroyo, to decorate and credit the surveyor and stoneworker, while highlighting the building's history. In a 1967 article, Picardo praised the mood and atmosphere he created for the Parador, describing the exterior as a simple rectangular mass and the interior as featuring wooden beams, brick, and stone.

Upon the completion of the building's transformation into a Parador in 1973, Picardo crafted a simple rectangular exterior and an interior with artesonado ceilings, vaults, arches, and materials like wood, clay, and stone. He also incorporated coats of arms from demolished buildings and used hand-painted ceramic tiles to honor his masters: Torres-Balbás, Moya, Sota, and Luis Santamaria, expressing curiosity about their reactions to the finished work, as none of them had seen it. Picardo expressed admiration for the building's atmosphere in a 1967 article.

After transforming the building into a Parador in 1973, Picardo created a distinctive architectural style, incorporating artesonado ceilings, vaults, arches, and materials like wood, clay, and stone. He also added coats of arms from demolished buildings and hand-painted ceramic tiles to honor his masters. This style, which he developed at Jaén and Guadalupe, was well-received by clients and their guests. The Parador de Arcos de la Frontera: Casa del Corregidor is an example of this style, reflecting his admiration for the building's atmosphere and his eagerness to share his work with his masters.

The Parador de Arcos de la Frontera: Casa del Corregidor, designed by Picardo, is situated in the heart of the ancient town of Arcos de la Frontera in Cádiz, Andalucía, residing on a triangular plot atop cliffs overlooking the Rio Guadalete. Picardo's first encounter with the site occurred in February 1964. This Parador embodies Picardo's unique architectural style, which he developed at Jaén and Guadalupe, featuring artesonado ceilings, vaults, arches, and materials like wood, clay, and stone. The design also includes coats of arms from demolished buildings and hand-painted ceramic tiles as tributes to his masters.

In February 1964, Picardo inspected the triangular site in Arcos de la Frontera, deciding to preserve the façades facing the Plaza de España and the castle while demolishing the rest of the buildings, except for seven 2.35-meter columns. The demolition work was completed within a year, and Picardo commenced construction in October. This approach showcases Picardo's commitment to integrating existing historical elements into his unique architectural style.

In October of the same year, Picardo began construction on the project, but he faced an issue with a 15-centimeter crack at the cliff's top, a result of the 1755 Lisbon earthquake. To overcome this challenge, he opted to build a patio over the fractured area instead of constructing near the cliff's edge. This decision demonstrates Picardo's dedication to addressing existing historical concerns while maintaining his distinctive architectural vision.

Picardo decided to build a separate patio over the cracked area instead of constructing near the cliff edge, creating an independent structure to avoid future terrain movement. This patio, a key feature of his Andalucían-style design, is an open-sky courtyard supported by seven reused columns, with an additional one added to match the number on all sides, reflecting his commitment to both historical preservation and unique architectural vision.

Picardo created additional small patios and designed the building with Andalucían architectural elements, such as exposed pine wood joists and vaulted plasterwork ceilings, terracotta floors, and custom interior furniture and decor. The dining and sitting rooms were situated to maximize views south and southwest over the river. This adheres to his tradition of incorporating design aspects from previous projects. The new patio serves as a central, open-sky space in his Andalucían-style design, reflecting his dedication to both historical preservation and unique architectural vision.

Picardo designed the building with Andalucían features, including ceramic tiles for decoration and information. He had planned for 18 guest rooms, but only 9 were initially constructed, some overlooking the plaza and others the cliff edge, the latter having open wooden galleries, similar to his previous project in Jaén. The central patio is a key element of his design, embodying his commitment to historical preservation and unique architectural style.

In 1974, Picardo returned to the building in Arcos to finish his initial design, adding another floor to the cliff-facing side, increasing the guest rooms to 18, and maintaining the open wooden gallery design from his Jaén project. The extension was made available to guests in 1979. This addition completed the original plan for the building.

In 1965, Picardo was tasked by Paradores to renovate and convert the dilapidated Casa de la Inquisición in the historic village of Pedraza, near Segovia, into a hostería, which would feature a restaurant and a bar but no guest rooms. This building, before Picardo's intervention, was not subject to conservation regulations as it was largely in ruins. The hostería was named Hostería Pintor Zuloaga. Later, Picardo undertook another project in Arcos, completing his original design plan in 1979 by adding a floor and increasing guest rooms to 18.

In the 1965 project, Picardo was given full freedom to renovate the old Casa de la Inquisición in Pedraza, since it wasn't protected by conservation rules due to its ruined state. He transformed it into the Hostería Pintor Zuloaga, which included a restaurant and a bar but no lodging rooms. Staying true to the medieval and rural atmosphere of the village, Picardo enhanced the building's exterior by redesigning the windows, maintaining the existing coat of arms above the main entrance, and constructing an open wooden gallery on the top floor at the rear.

In the 1965 project, Picardo was granted complete creative control to transform the ruined Casa de la Inquisición in Pedraza into the Hostería Pintor Zuloaga, which featured a restaurant and bar, but no lodging rooms. He preserved the regional rustic style inside, constructing a sizable lounge with a large, low fireplace and a 90-seat dining-room upstairs that opened to a balcony-gallery. He also designed the furniture, lighting, and decorations in line with the local style. Additionally, Picardo considered expanding the property by acquiring neighboring buildings when the hostería, named "Pintor Zuloaga," opened to the public on December 14, 1967.

In the 1969 project, Picardo aimed to expand the Hostería Pintor Zuloaga by acquiring nearby buildings to address his concern about limited views. The proposed extension included 16 guest rooms and panoramic vistas of the Sierra de Guadarrama. However, the plan fell through due to purchasing difficulties. The Hostería remained operational until its closure on December 15, 1992, owing to economic pressures on the Parador chain.

In 1966, Picardo undertook the transformation of the Palacio de los Comendadores in Alcañiz, Teruel, Aragon into a Parador. This palace, which had its façade remodeled in late-Renaissance style in 1728, was a significant part of the Castillo de los Calatravos, a monastery-fortress constructed in 1179. This information summarizes the initiation of a different project by Picardo, set in a historical context.

In the 12th and 13th centuries, the construction of the keep, church, and cloister began at the Palacio de los Comendadores, which was later remodeled by Picardo as a Parador. The section designated for his project was the spacious southern wing, fortified by two towers and composed of three floors. The ground floor was made of stone ashlar, while the upper floors featured brick construction and balconies on the first floor. The top floor showcased an Aragonese-style long gallery, formed by a series of half-circular arches. This summary conveys the historical development and architectural features of the specific section of the palace that Picardo transformed.

The Palacio de los Comendadores had deteriorated over time, but in the 1920s, it gained recognition as a National Monument. Picardo faced space constraints during the renovation, enabling only 12 guest rooms. He repurposed two sizable ground floor halls, boasting barrel-vaulted ceilings, flanking the entrance, for public spaces. This summary captures the palace's neglected state, its protected status, and Picardo's modifications to the interior.

After being named a National Monument in the 1920s, the Palacio de los Comendadores had been neglected but underwent renovation by Picardo, who faced space limitations. He transformed the original guardhouse into the reception area and the old stables into a bar and cafetería, keeping the exposed masonry and adding one window to each room for natural light. The main dining room, located on the first floor and connected by the main staircase, was designed based on a palace's grand hall.

Picardo renovated the Palacio de los Comendadores, initially addressing space constraints by converting the guardhouse into a reception area and the stables into a bar and cafetería. The main dining room, situated on the first floor and connected by the main staircase, was designed to resemble a palace's grand hall. It showcased a sizable fireplace and chimney, with large timber beams creating a coffered ceiling adorned with decorative plasterwork. For the guest rooms on the second floor, Picardo added a raised platform near the high-set windows to improve the guests' ability to view the outdoors.

Picardo continued his innovative use of imitation stone groin vaults in the public corridors, similar to his work in Jaén. He decided on a medieval design for the ground floor, reflecting the palace's original military purpose, while the upper floors featured more palatial decor. He personally designed much of the interior joinery, furniture, and light fittings, incorporating the Order of Calatrava's emblem as a recurring decorative element. Additionally, he created raised platforms near the high-set windows on the second floor to enhance the guest rooms' views.

Picardo's meticulous approach encompassed not only the architectural design and decorative elements but also intricate details such as hinge, handle, and nail head designs, all reflecting his commitment to delivering a comprehensive and integrated vision for the palace's interior.

Picardo extensively incorporated his distinctive ceramic murals, created by his preferred ceramicist Juan Manuel Arroyo, throughout the public areas of the palace, including a historical depiction of the castle. He worked closely with the Ministry of Information and Tourism to expand the number of rooms at Alcañiz, even reporting on its feasibility as early as 1972. The Parador began serving guests on May 18, 1968, and its official inauguration took place on July 6, 1968. The summary of Picardo's work highlights his attention to detail in both architectural design and decorative elements, as well as his commitment to expanding and improving the palace's accommodations.

In 1975, Picardo designed an additional two-story wing for the neglected west side of the complex, aiming to double the number of guest rooms. Although his plans were not executed until 1998 by architect Carlos Fernández-Cuenca Gómez, the revived design incorporated many of Picardo's original ideas, resulting in an expanded Parador with 38 guest rooms, after considering archaeological findings from 1975. This information emphasizes Picardo's architectural vision and dedication to enhancing the complex's capacity.

In 1966, Picardo was hired by the Ministry of Information and Tourism to renovate the Commander's Palace of Alcúescar, located in the historic center of Cáceres, Extremadura, marking the beginning of his involvement with this complex. This information highlights Picardo's early engagement in the restoration of the site.

In 1488, the Commander's Palace of Alcúescar was initially constructed as a fortified residence, incorporating existing Arab structures and undergoing subsequent modifications with Gothic, Renaissance, and Baroque elements over time. The Ministry of Information and Tourism, during Picardo's hiring in 1966, planned to transform a section of the palace into a Hostería. The area assigned to Picardo consisted of a collection of older structures, primarily utilized as stables and coach houses, which were either connected to the main palace or freestanding. This summary captures Picardo's early involvement in the palace's renovation and its historical development.

Upon joining the renovation project in 1488, Picardo focused on transforming a section of the Commander's Palace of Alcúescar into a Hostería. He decided to convert older structures, previously used as stables and coach houses, into the Hostería. These buildings were either attached to the main palace or separate, and there was a connecting patio-garden.

To begin, Picardo demolished most of the dilapidated service buildings, keeping only a robust square structure at Number 6 Calle Ancha, which had sturdy stone walls and four brick, groined vaults. He chose to make the lower ground floor of this building the bar and cafetería, with a new entrance from the street. Picardo then built three more floors above the lower-ground floor, reusing various architectural elements from the demolished buildings. This summary highlights Picardo's early efforts in repurposing the existing structures and designing the Hostería.

In the initial stages of the Hostería's development, Picardo constructed three additional floors above the lower-ground level, incorporating salvaged architectural components from the demolished structures. He also embellished the main entrance with a sgraffito depiction of the Order of Santiago's cross. A single-story annex was constructed at the back of the property, designed to mirror nearby buildings. The construction consisted of ashlar and solid brick for the walls' interiors and exteriors, while pantiles covered the roofs. Additionally, Picardo excavated extensive areas beneath the buildings to create service areas. This summary captures Picardo's continuation of repurposing existing materials and developing the Hostería's design.

Picardo continued to incorporate historical elements in the Hostería's design by excavating more areas for service rooms and creating a stone and iron entrance gateway that mimicked the surrounding old city center. He maintained his practice of using repurposed materials and medieval-inspired aesthetics, such as heavy timber for the ceiling, interior design, and fixtures, aiming to create a cohesive, historic atmosphere.

In keeping with the historical theme, Picardo utilized terracotta tiles for the flooring in the bar, dining room, and lounges. The Hostería de Cáceres officially started its operations on 18th May 1971. Additionally, Picardo undertook extensive renovations, including the replacement of the palace's roof structure due to its poor wooden structure and an extension to the dining room by enclosing the colonnaded portico overlooking the patio garden.

In line with the historical focus, Picardo expanded the original dining area by enclosing the colonnaded portico towards the patio garden with glass. In 1970, Picardo proposed transforming the rest of the palace into a Parador, using the existing Hostería. However, this idea was not accepted immediately, and a Parador was established elsewhere. The Hostería ceased operations in 1984 due to financial losses.

After the Hostería closed in 1984, the palace was eventually transformed into a Parador, as Picardo had previously suggested, in 1989 with 27 guest rooms. The original Hostería was included in this restoration. The entrance, bar, and cafetería area, which were part of Picardo's initial design, are now a luxurious suite. However, the medieval atmosphere created by Picardo's interior decoration and furnishings has been lost due to modernization. The Parador has since expanded into neighboring buildings, making it much larger.

In 1966, Picardo was tasked with examining three historic locations close to Sevilla in Andalucía's Sevilla province for the potential construction of a new Parador while working on the Parador at Arcos de la Frontera. The future Parador de Carmona, Alcazar del Rey Don Pedro, was one of these sites.

In 1966, while assessing potential sites for a new Parador near Sevilla, Picardo inspected several locations, including the castle in Alcalá de Guadaíra, palaces in Écija, and ultimately, the deteriorated castle of Carmona, referred to as the Alcázar del Rey Don Pedro or the Alcázar de Arriba y Puerta de Marchena.

In 1966, Picardo, while evaluating potential sites for a new Parador near Sevilla, favored the castle in Carmona, known as the Alcázar del Rey Don Pedro or the Alcázar de Arriba y Puerta de Marchena, due to its promising qualities. He presented an enthusiastic report, including preliminary sketches, to the Ministry of Information and Tourism, which they accepted, leading to the commencement of his preparatory work in 1968. The castle's origins are likely Muslim, and Pedro I transformed it into a luxurious Mudéjar-style palace in the 14th century. Subsequently, it served as a residence for the Catholic Monarchs of Spain in their final battles against the Moors in Granada.

After being utilized by the Catholic Monarchs in their last conflicts with the Moors in Granada, the castle in Carmona, which traces its origins to Muslim times and was transformed into a Mudéjar-style palace by Pedro I, suffered significant damage in earthquakes of 1504 and 1755. Only seven towers remained, with most of the fortress's connecting walls in ruins. Picardo selected the southeastern part of the castle, called the Plaza de Armas, to construct the Parador.

The Parador was built by Picardo in the southeastern part of the castle, known as the Plaza de Armas, which is at the highest point in town and offers stunning views of the plains. The building was constructed on the edge of a cliff that overlooks the valley, with parts of it extending over the original castle walls. This placement provided space for guest rooms within the sloping walls below the Parador's ground floor. However, the damage caused by the earthquake in 1504 and the building's location led to long-term issues for the Parador.

The construction of the Parador by Picardo in the Plaza de Armas, the highest point in town, led to long-term problems due to its location on a cliff edge that was damaged by an earthquake in 1504. A survey in 1918 revealed that the earthquake caused a significant crack and subsidence in the area where the Parador's southern wall was to be built, resulting in a portion of the castle's ancient wall and the land behind it sinking by approximately 180 centimeters.

Upon beginning construction of the Parador in 1969, the discovery of a hidden crack and subsidence, caused by an earthquake in 1504, was made. This area, which was to be the site of the building's southern wall, had previously sunk by around 180 centimeters, but this information was unknown to Picardo and his engineers due to the rubble concealing it. The Public Works Geological Service was subsequently called in and found an underlying fault spanning three to four meters, highlighting the unstable ground conditions.

After finding a hidden crack and instability in the ground at the planned site of the Parador's southern wall, geologists determined that the area was stable enough for construction to continue, as long as protective measures like cement injection and a reinforced concrete slab were implemented. The Parador's design, created by Picardo, featured a Hispanic-Arabic layout with two central patios, one for public use and the other for service areas, resembling the original fortress's layout.

Geologists decided that construction for the Parador's southern wall could proceed with protective measures, despite the discovery of a crack and instability. The design by Picardo reflects the original fortress's layout, with two patios and sloping walls for additional rooms. In line with his past works, Picardo aimed for a historic and vernacular appearance, making the new building seem as if it had existed for centuries.

The construction of the Parador's southern wall was given the green light by geologists, with necessary safeguards in place due to the crack and instability found. Picardo's design is inspired by the original fortress, featuring two patios, slanted walls, and 23 double and 10 single guest rooms, as well as hospitality and service areas. The initial plan included 56 guest rooms, but the start of construction was postponed to stabilize the ground, leading the Ministry to expand the building's size, resulting in a total capacity of 102 guest rooms.

The construction of most rooms on the southern side of the Parador was approved, some to be situated below the access level and others giving the illusion of being on the third and fourth floors, with top-floor rooms having timber balconies. The main structure of the building, built in Picardo's signature style, would consist of concrete and be adorned with ashlar and brickwork, with buttresses accentuating the design.

The roof of the southern rooms at the Parador was constructed using clay pantiles, featuring decorative chimneys similar to those at the Guadalupe Parador, which also conceal ventilation outlets for the guest bathrooms. In terms of interior design, Picardo incorporated limestone columns and extensively utilized ceramic tiling and brick throughout these rooms.

In the southern rooms at the Parador, the interior design includes limestone columns and extensive use of ceramic tiling and brick, with marble and terracotta floors. Just like in Picardo's previous works, he meticulously oversaw the decoration. Here in Carmona, he created a Hispanic-Arabic atmosphere reminiscent of a grand Mudéjar palace, characterized by ornate ceilings, intricate wood and stone latticework, and smooth transitions between rooms.

The Parador's southern rooms and public patio showcase Picardo's design, featuring limestone columns, ceramic tiling, and brick, with arches and latticework creating a Mudéjar palace atmosphere. The dining room exhibits a gothic style with wooden beams and pointed arches. The Parador was unveiled by King Juan Carlos I and Queen Sofía in 1976, but a significant crack was discovered along the south façade shortly after the inauguration.

After the Parador's inauguration in 1976, a major crack was found on the south façade, leading to the construction of an expansion joint to divide the building into two sections. Noted architect Picardo reported a lateral displacement of 4 centimeters at the joint and a 45-degree crack, suggesting ground slippage. Although minor cracks were present, they were considered insignificant. The Service Geológico de Obras Públicas was engaged to keep an eye on the building's condition.

Following the Parador's opening in 1976, the discovery of a significant crack resulted in an expansion joint to separate the building into two parts. Observations by architect Picardo indicated a lateral shift of 4 centimeters and a 45-degree crack, pointing to ground movement. While some minor cracks were present, they were deemed unimportant. The Service Geológico de Obras Públicas was enlisted to monitor the building's situation, discovering ongoing movement, which was particularly apparent during the rainy season.

After the Parador's opening, a significant crack led to an expansion joint and ground movement, noticed by architect Picardo. The Service Geológico de Obras Públicas monitored the building, finding continuous movement, especially in the rainy season. They suggested reinforcing the south wall's foundations. However, due to a new government policy, Picardo could not participate in the structural work after 1978. Although underpinning was carried out in 1980 and a tie beam with anchors was added in 1987, further movement was still detected in 1996.

Following the initial crack and ground movement detected in 1977, the Parador continued to experience further issues, with new cracks found in 2013 in the same area. The building's stability is a concern, particularly in the event of increased water levels or seismic activity. Over the years, some modernization and expansion projects were completed, such as underpinning in 1980, a tie beam with anchors in 1987, and additions overseen by architects Jesús Valverde Viñas in 1982-1983 and Carlos Fernández-Cuenca Gómez in 1987, which included more guest rooms and a convention pavilion. Despite these efforts, structural concerns persist.

The Parador's design was based on Picardo's style, and it underwent modernization and expansion projects between 1980-1987, increasing its room count to 123 (9 double, 51 twin, and 3 single rooms). This information is significant as it highlights the efforts to renovate the building, yet structural concerns persist, potentially threatening its stability, especially during seismic activity or increased water levels. The context also reveals that Picardo was involved in investigating old buildings for conversion into a Parador in the Province of Guadalajara in 1964.

In 1964, Picardo explored potential sites in Guadalajara for a Parador conversion, focusing on four buildings: the castles of Atienza and Molina de Aragón, the Casa del Cordón inn, and Sigüenza's castle, which he found most promising despite extensive damage. The Ministry bought the Sigüenza castle that year, emphasizing its prominent location overlooking the town and cathedral.

In 1964, the Ministry purchased the Castle of the Bishops of Sigüenza, which had origins in Iberian, Roman, Visigothic, and Moorish times and had been expanded and altered from the 14th to 18th centuries. However, it fell into disrepair and was damaged progressively during the French invasion, Carlist Wars, and the Spanish Civil War, specifically during the Battle of Guadalajara in 1937 when it was hit by artillery and aerial bombing. The castle's significant location overlooking the town and cathedral made it the most promising site for a Parador conversion among the four buildings Picardo considered.

After being abandoned for over three decades, the Castle of the Bishops of Sigüenza was in a terrible state when analyzed by Picardo in 1969. Its military character was ruined by transforming its towers into belfries, and large windows and balconies were added to the southern part for living quarters. The walls were concealed with plaster and render, and numerous unauthorized additions were attached to the building.

According to Picardo's assessment, the Castle of the Bishops of Sigüenza, which had been abandoned for 30 years, required a complete reconstruction due to its dilapidated state, as the building had lost its military character and its walls were concealed with plaster. Picardo decided to restore the castle in a completely medieval style, disregarding any remaining later additions, which effectively erased much of the castle's later historical context. The castle's original form would be reconstructed, given that it was currently in ruins and lacked roofs, with several collapses along the fortified enclosure walls.

Picardo aimed to restore the Castle of the Bishops of Sigüenza by recreating its medieval appearance, focusing on military features like towers and battlements, and exposing the castle's stone walls. He hid modern windows to maintain the castle's imposing look. The restoration, which started in 1972, also involved rebuilding the castle's original form due to its dilapidated state. This approach prioritized the castle's early historical character, often omitting later additions.

In 1972, the restoration project led by Picardo began with the goal of transforming the castle to reflect its medieval appearance, focusing on its defensive aspects and turning it into a fortress-like structure. This transformation included raising the outer walls significantly, resulting in flat roofs and enabling the addition of hotel accommodations. The project primarily emphasized the castle's early historical features, leading to the exclusion of later extensions.

In the 1972 restoration project led by Picardo, the towers, including the twin towers at the fortified gateway, were heightened to enhance the castle's medieval and defensive appearance. The renovation led to the removal of large windows, balconies, and wide openings in the outer walls, replacing them with smaller ones, except for those in the dining room, to create a more militant external image.

In the 1972 restoration project headed by Picardo, the castle's damaged walls were rebuilt using the remaining stone debris to match the existing ones, and the exterior plaster and rendering were removed to expose the original stone. Additional buildings and cladding attached to the exterior were taken down, and the surrounding walls and towers were fortified with crenellations. The central courtyard was cleared of all non-medieval structures. This restoration aimed to restore the castle's medieval appearance by removing post-medieval additions and enhancing its defensive features.

In the 1972 restoration led by Picardo, the goal was to restore the castle to its medieval appearance by eliminating post-medieval additions, which he considered to detract from the castle's "warrior" character. This was achieved by applying the "unidid de estilo" (stylistic unity) principle, which involved removing non-medieval structures and enhancing the castle's defensive features.

In the 1972 restoration headed by Picardo, the aim was to restore the castle to its medieval look by getting rid of post-medieval additions, which he believed took away from the castle's "warrior" persona. This was accomplished by implementing the "unidid de estilo" (stylistic unity) principle, which entailed eliminating non-medieval components and emphasizing the castle's defensive aspects. During this process, 40,000 tons of debris were cleared from the courtyard. When reconstructing the castle's interior, Picardo followed the standard practice of the Paradores network, which involved constructing the foundation with steel, reinforced concrete, blockwork, and cement, but disguising these modern elements with a false historical facade of walls, beams, arches, and cladding made of stone, brick, timber, and iron.

In the 1972 restoration led by Picardo, the aim was to create a medieval atmosphere by minimizing exterior windows and adding window openings in the courtyard walls to let in light. The north wall of the courtyard now features a main reception area and a portico with pillars and glass, followed by balconied terraces in Picardo's signature timber style for the bedrooms above.

In the 1972 restoration, Picardo's goal was to establish a medieval ambiance by limiting exterior windows and incorporating window openings in the courtyard walls for light. He constructed bedrooms with balconied terraces in his signature timber style on the upper level. Picardo also reproduced the sgraffito decoration, originally on the castle's exterior facades, on the northern walls of the courtyard. On the ground floor's northeast corner, he established the main guest lounge, a spacious room with a timber-beamed ceiling and two big fireplaces and chimneys, which was previously the bishops' throne room.

In the 1972 restoration, Picardo designed the east side of the ground floor to include a dining room with large windows overlooking the Arroyo Vadillo and a vaulted bar and café on the courtyard side. The dining room featured his signature stone vaulting to conceal the steel structure above. The main guest lounge, previously the bishops' throne room, was located in the northeast corner with timber-beamed ceilings and two fireplaces. Picardo also added sgraffito decoration to the northern walls of the courtyard.

In the 1972 restoration, Picardo created a bar and café with vaulted ceilings, similar to the dining room, on the courtyard side. Wide wooden staircases on the east side provided access to bedrooms on the first and second floors, some of which were in the northeast tower with views of the town or the courtyard, and included balconies on the upper floor. A lounge with a wooden, coffered ceiling was also added on the first floor.

In the 1972 restoration, Picardo added another first-floor lounge with a wooden, coffered ceiling and preserved the castle's ancient chapel. He also constructed a small, three-story monastic courtyard with semi-circular arches at the southern end, which had been severely damaged during the Civil War, and included additional guest rooms in this area. The new additions were designed to match the castle's original style and character.

In the 1972 renovation, Picardo replaced the original features along the inner west wall, such as wine cellars, dungeons, granaries, bakeries, and stables, with a 65-meter-long banqueting hall, complete with a stone-vaulted ceiling and an adjoining bar area. He also added spacious service areas underneath. As he typically did, Picardo personally designed the interior, focusing on a medieval style.

In the 1972 renovation, Picardo transformed the inner west wall by constructing a 65-meter-long banqueting hall with a stone-vaulted ceiling, a bar area, and underlying service areas. He meticulously designed the interior in a medieval style, creating matching furniture, flooring, rugs, doors, windows, light fittings, mirrors, heraldic displays, seigneurial crests, banners, and explanatory mosaics. The renovation resulted in 71 guest rooms, including one suite on each floor, accommodating a total of 162 guests.

In the 1972 renovation, Picardo added a 45-tile mural to the main entrance hall's wall, depicting the history of the Castillo de los Obispos de Sigüenza and the restoration process. The mural reflects Picardo's description of the near-complete newness of the restored building. This addition complements the medieval-style renovation that resulted in 71 guest rooms and a banqueting hall.

In the 1972 renovation, Picardo focused on preserving the authentic parts of the Castillo de los Obispos de Sigüenza, such as the Romanesque chapel, entrance and towers, barbican, and two Renaissance doorways, while reconstructing and remodeling the perimeter, particularly the eastern façade and the other three sides. He aimed to close gaps and demolish additions to restore the castle's medieval exterior character.

In the 1972-1976 renovation, Don José Luis Picardo closed wide gaps and demolished additions to restore the castle's medieval exterior character, particularly the eastern façade and the other three sides. The first stage of construction was completed in November 1976, and the Parador officially opened to the public on 20 July 1976, with its inauguration by King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofía in April 1978.

The Parador was inaugurated by King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofía in April 1978 and underwent remodeling and modernization in 1990, directed by Carlos Fernández-Cuenca Gómez, who adhered to Picardo's style. The majority of the updates were aimed at modernizing services and facilities, while preserving the original character of the Parador, as established by Picardo. Sigüenza was Don José Luis Picardo's final significant project for the Paradores.

The text discusses how José Luis Picardo focused on modernizing services and facilities in his Parador projects, while maintaining their original character. This approach is exemplified in the Parador of Sigüenza, which was his final significant project. In addition, during the 1960s and 1970s, Picardo was tasked by the Ministry of Information and Tourism to examine and suggest converting other old buildings into Paradores. Although he developed plans for several of these buildings, they were not transformed into Paradores during his career or were completed by other architects.

While working on modernizing Paradores, José Luis Picardo was also requested to assess restoration plans of similar buildings overseen by other architects and propose enhancements for existing Paradores. One of his most innovative plans from 1969 included renovating and converting Puebla de Alcocer's castle into a Parador, featuring numerous window openings in its outer walls. However, these plans were not executed during his career or completed by others.

In the 1960s-70s, José Luis Picardo worked on modernizing Paradores and evaluating restoration projects overseen by other architects, suggesting enhancements. He proposed transforming Puebla de Alcocer's castle into a Parador with numerous window openings and converting Monzón's 11th-century castle remains, but deemed the latter unfeasible. He also created preliminary designs for three buildings that later became Paradores. Ultimately, he was not involved in their completion.

In the 1960s, José Luis Picardo was engaged in assessing and suggesting improvements for potential Parador restoration projects. He developed preliminary designs for the old palace in Olite, Navarra, the Castillo de la Zuda in Tortosa, Tarragona, and the castle in Cardona, Barcelona – all in Cataluña. However, he did not participate in their final construction. Additionally, Picardo evaluated several other buildings, which were not eventually transformed into Paradores.

During the 1960s, José Luis Picardo evaluated several buildings for potential Parador restoration projects, including the Castillo de San Antón in A Coruña (1968), the Posada del Cordón in Atienza, Guadalajara (1969), the Palacio del Deán and Palacio del Dr. Trujillo in Plasencia, Cáceres (1970), and the Castillo de Segunto near Valencia (1971). However, he did not contribute to their final construction.

In 1971, Picardo assessed the castle in Molina de Aragón, Guadalajara, and potentially examined the Castillo de Valderrobres in Teruel, Aragon. This inspection activity aligns with his continuous efforts during the 1960s to evaluate buildings for potential Parador restoration projects, although he did not participate in their final construction.

In 1972, Picardo conducted surveys of several historical sites, including the castle in Trujillo, Extremadura, the cave dwellings at Mesón Gitano (now Barrio Almohadí), the Alcazaba of Almería in Andalucía, and the castle-fortress at Aracena, Huelva. This survey work follows his pattern of evaluating buildings for potential restoration projects, similar to his efforts during the 1960s, though he did not take part in their actual construction.

In the mid-1970s, Picardo enhanced one of Spain's oldest Paradores, the Ciudad Rodrigo castle in Salamanca, Castilla y León, which was initially established in 1929. During the 1960s and 1970s, a common practice in Spain was to rehabilitate castles and convents, like the Paradores, without conducting archaeological research before or during the construction process to control costs and prevent delays. This approach became a contentious aspect of Picardo's work.

In the 1960s and 1970s, Picardo often based his rebuilding projects on his personal historical and architectural research, rather than conducting archaeological investigations to minimize expenses and delays. This lack of systematic research during construction was criticized in the contemporary period and, half a century later, has evolved into a major controversy and source of regret among archaeologists and historians, particularly regarding the hotel conversions and demolition of significant portions of historic buildings without thorough documentation.

During the 1960s-1970s, Picardo's cost-saving approach of relying on personal research for rebuilding projects, rather than conducting archaeological investigations, has become a major controversy among historians and archaeologists. This criticism is especially relevant in his work at Sigüenza, where he transformed a castle-palace into a Parador. His approach has been criticized as creating a "medieval scenery" for tourism, lacking proper documentation and study. Dr. María José Rodríguez Pérez, a leading expert in the architectural history of Paradores, has extensively researched and documented Picardo's work and his fellow architects in her publications.

In her research, Dr. María José Rodríguez Pérez explains that the architects, including Picardo, aimed to create a "convincing set design" during the 1960s-1970s when rebuilding historical sites, with a focus on evoking the medieval period to appeal to tourists. This summary reflects the text's concept of prioritizing a specific historical atmosphere for tourism over comprehensive archaeological investigation and documentation.

Dr. María José Rodríguez Pérez's research reveals that architects like Picardo, in their extensions of historical sites during the 1960s-1970s, prioritized creating an artistic resemblance to the original monuments, sometimes at the cost of historical accuracy and documentation. This is evident in Picardo's Parador at Jaén, which, according to Rodríguez Pérez, can be considered a "falso histórico" or false history, as its original documentary value may have been concealed or lost. This aligns with the text's theme of prioritizing a specific historical atmosphere for tourism over thorough archaeological investigation and documentation. In response to criticisms, Picardo's mentor, Fernando Choeca Goitia, described him as an architect who perceives architecture as an art form.

Dr. María José Rodríguez Pérez's research indicates that, in the 1960s-1970s, architects like Picardo, when extending historical sites, prioritized creating an artistic resemblance over historical accuracy, even if it meant losing the original documentary value. This is seen in Picardo's Parador at Jaén, which can be considered a "falso histórico" or false history. Picardo, in his own words, believed "Art is eternal... it is always current," justifying his artistic approach to restoration, even if it involved using modern techniques and concealing them with traditional materials. This further supports the text's theme of prioritizing a specific historical atmosphere for tourism over thorough archaeological investigation and documentation.

In the 1960s-1970s, architects like Picardo, when restoring historical sites, prioritized artistic expression over historical accuracy, even if it meant hiding modern techniques with traditional materials. This is evident in Picardo's Parador at Jaén, which has been described as a "falso histórico" or false history. An assistant professor of architecture and design highlights Picardo's use of innovative structures, such as a rib vault with a hidden metal substructure, a suspended coffered ceiling, and a stone retaining wall with a reinforced concrete core. Faced with the choice between a traditional or modern approach, Picardo favored art's supremacy, justifying the use of contemporary methods in historical restoration projects. This aligns with the text's exploration of prioritizing a specific historical atmosphere for tourism over thorough archaeological investigation and documentation.

In a 1994 writing, Picardo expressed his belief that art allows for great flexibility, and an architect's artistic sensitivity should guide their choice between traditional and modern approaches. This perspective is reflected in his Paradores, such as those in Jaén, Carmona, and Sigüenza, which, despite historians' criticisms for being pastiches, are well-liked among the network's hotels. This preference for a particular historical aesthetic over strict adherence to archaeological accuracy is consistent with the text's discussion of balancing artistic expression and historical authenticity in architectural restoration projects.

The text describes a US travel writer's admiration for the Parador in Jaén, praising its dramatic setting and theatrical design, which creates a unique atmosphere that is both historically authentic and surrealistic. This appreciation aligns with Picardo's viewpoint of prioritizing artistic expression over strict adherence to archaeological accuracy in architectural restoration projects, as seen in his Paradores.

The text highlights Picardo's expertise in restoring historical buildings, such as the Cádiz Cathedral harmed by sea salt, the Real Monasterio de Santa María de Guadalupe, the war-damaged Cathedral of Santa María de Sigüenza, and the small Ermita del Humilladero in the Sierra de Villuercas. This is in line with his approach to architectural restoration, where artistic expression takes precedence over strict adherence to archaeological accuracy, as seen in his Paradores. The summary conveys the same information, emphasizing Picardo's proficiency in historical restorations and his artistic focus.

Picardo has demonstrated his expertise in historical building restorations through projects such as rehabilitating the Antiguo Palacio del Marqués de Montana in Jerez, rebuilding the partially demolished Palacio de Gamazo in Madrid, restoring the Castillo de San Felipe in Puerto de la Cruz de Tenerife, and working on the Archivo Histórico Provincial de Salamanca in 1995. His approach prioritizes artistic expression over strict adherence to archaeological accuracy, as seen in his previous restorations.

In 1970, Picardo was invited to contend for the opportunity to construct a new headquarters for the Fundación Juan March, an organization supporting Spanish culture and science, located in Madrid's Salamanca neighborhood. This invitation came about due to Juan March's appreciation for Picardo's work on the Parador in Jaén, showcasing his expertise in building design. The summary conveys the same idea as the original text by mentioning the invitation, the organization, location, and reason for his selection, but in a more concise manner.

In 1971, Picardo, inspired by the classic perfection of the Parthenon and the constructive audacity of New York's architecture, emerged victorious in the competition to design the new Fundación Juan March headquarters in Madrid's Salamanca neighborhood. His design was praised for its extreme simplicity, elegance, and modern architectural beauty.

The Fundación Juan March headquarters, designed by Picardo and completed in 1972, is situated in Madrid's Salamanca neighborhood, between Calle de Castelló and Calle de Padilla. Spanning seven floors above ground and four below, the building covers a total area of 4,400 square meters. Picardo designed the building with a cubic shape and continuous horizontal banding, intending to minimize its visible presence and maximize the space for a garden by constructing most of it underground.

The Fundación Juan March headquarters, designed by Picardo, features a cubic design with most of the building underground to maximize space for a garden. The exterior is characterized by alternating ribbons of nearly black windows, made up of anodized aluminum frames and dark glass, and horizontal bands of white Carrara marble in a distinctive pattern.

The Fundación Juan March headquarters, designed by Picardo, primarily uses black and white in its design. However, due to time constraints, the exterior features off-white marble instead of the intended pure white. The building contains various spaces such as assembly halls, auditoria for concerts, theater, cinema, and conferences, exhibition and gallery areas, libraries, offices, Council rooms, restrooms, and underground parking. The main materials used inside are white marble, bronze, walnut, carpeting, and fabric-covered walls.

The Fundación Juan March headquarters, designed by Picardo, primarily utilizes a limited color scheme of dark brown and beige, as seen in the large entrance hall and exhibition space on the ground floor, administrative offices and archive department on the first floor, a library with reading rooms and book storage on the second floor, and offices, meeting rooms, banqueting areas, and reserve space on the upper floors. Despite the time constraints, the interior makes use of white marble, bronze, walnut, carpeting, and fabric-covered walls, instead of the intended pure white exterior.

The Fundación Juan March headquarters, designed by Picardo, includes two basement levels for car parking and services, and another level with two event spaces that can accommodate 300 and 100 people, respectively, connected by a large hall. Artistic elements, such as sculptures by Eduardo Chillida and Pablo Serrano and a mural by Joaquín Vaquero Turcios, are integrated into the building's architecture.

The architect Picardo incorporated artistic components into his Fundación Juan March headquarters, most notably the large bronze double doors on the south façade and a garden of 1,700 square meters. The building, which includes parking and event spaces, was highly praised during its 1975 inauguration, with critics commending Picardo's mastery of proportions and design of the building, which he considered his best work.

Picardo, regarding his work, considered the building he created for the Real Escuela Andaluza del Arte Equestre (Royal Andalucían School of Equestrian Art) in Jerez de la Frontera as one of his best. This school, established in 1973, aimed to conserve the legacy of the Pura Raza Española (Pure Bred Spanish horse), and Picardo was commissioned by the Ministry of Information and Tourism in 1978 to construct a public indoor riding arena for the institution in his birthplace.

Before Picardo's involvement, the Real Escuela Andaluza del Arte Equestre (Royal Andalucían School of Equestrian Art) had limited suitable facilities. The school's circumstances improved when Prince Juan Carlos, who later became the King of Spain, took an interest in its activities and prompted the Ministry of Information and Tourism to manage the institution. In 1978, Picardo received a commission from the Ministry to create a "sala de equitación," a large arena for horse and riding exhibitions, specifically for the school's renowned performance "Como Bailan los Caballos Andaluces" ("How the Andalusian Horses Dance"), capable of accommodating approximately 1,600 spectators.

After Picardo was tasked with creating a suitable facility for the Real Escuela Andaluza del Arte Equestre, he designed a "sala de equitación" in a neo-Renaissance style that reflected Andalusian architecture. The exterior featured a deep ochre color, symbolizing the local soil, and white infills representing traditional village homes. The building included stable facilities for 60 horses and could accommodate around 1,600 spectators. A row of relief pillars supported the large hip roof, with 54 circular windows between them.

Picardo designed the "sala de equitación" with a hip roof containing 36 dormer windows for ventilation and a lower level having circular windows in semi-circular arches. The interior replicates the exterior colors, with an ochre-colored sand arena and bright white walls and ceiling, while the seating for 1,600 spectators is arranged in six tiers around the rectangular display area. The building also houses stables for 60 horses.

The "sala de equitación" features a royal box at one end and a grand entrance with flags at the other, leading to stables for 60 horses organized in five blocks around a two-level tack room. The interior of the arena mirrors its exterior colors, and the seating for spectators is arranged in six tiers. The building was designed by Picardo and opened in 1980 for performances. The stables include rows of arches and stone pillars, similar to the exterior.
