In 1981, Picasso's anti-war masterpiece, "Guernica," was transferred from the Museum of Modern Art in New York to the Museo Nacional del Prado in Madrid, fulfilling the artist's wish for its permanent display. This change occurred a year after the "sala de equitación" was inaugurated in 1980, a building designed by Picardo featuring a royal box, grand entrance, seating for spectators in six tiers, and stables for 60 horses. The "sala de equitación" also includes interior colors that match its exterior and is adorned with arches and stone pillars, similar to the exterior stables.

In 1981, Picasso's "Guernica" was moved to the Museo Nacional del Prado in Madrid, as per his desire. The painting was installed in the Salón de Luca Giordano, located in the Casón del Buen Retiro annexe. Picardo and José García María de Paredes, leading a technical team, were responsible for designing a secure display for the painting, which included armored glass to safeguard it from potential damage caused by bombs, bullets, and vandalism.

In 1981, when Picasso's "Guernica" was placed in the Museo Nacional del Prado, the largest available armored glass was not large enough to display the entire painting. The architects, Picardo and José García María de Paredes, resolved this issue by positioning the painting at a certain distance from the glass sheet, preventing the metal frame from obstructing the view of the artwork.

In 1981, Picasso's "Guernica" was displayed at the Museo Nacional del Prado using an armored glass and steel case as a solution to protect the painting. This case was designed with beveled edges that connected with the floor, walls, and ceiling for maximum security. The main glass panel was angled at 10 degrees from the vertical to minimize reflections, and the lighting was installed inside the case to illuminate the artwork.

In 1981, Picasso's "Guernica" was exhibited at the Museo Nacional del Prado, enclosed in a custom case with internal lighting. The spacious room, previously a ballroom, enabled viewing of the entire artwork from 25 meters away. The painting was installed in September and the public could access it starting October 25, which marked Picasso's centenary. Over a million individuals viewed "Guernica" in its new display within a year, despite varying opinions on the presentation method.

The display method of "Guernica" at the Museo Nacional del Prado received various reactions. Picasso's daughter, Paloma Picasso, and Spanish artist Josep Renau praised the location and presentation. Architect Josep Lluís Sert described it as magnificent. British art critic Douglas Cooper commended the lighting, stating that the painting had never been displayed more beautifully. However, not all shared these positive views.

The display of "Guernica" at the Museo Nacional del Prado faced criticism from some individuals. The use of technicians from Círculo de Bellas Artes instead of the Prado's staff led to practical issues. Years after the painting's return to Spain in 1981, British art critic David Sylvester argued that its placement in an annex of the Prado was not ideal and did not showcase the painting effectively.

In 1992, "Guernica" was transferred from Museo Nacional del Prado to a specially designed gallery at Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía, following controversies over its previous location. This move ended the use of the Picardo/García de Paredes display installation. The painting's new location was a result of elections in the Real Academia.

In 1997, Picardo, then 78 years old, was elected as a member of the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando, following a proposal by Julio Cano Lasso, Fernando Chueca Goitia, and Luis García-Ochoa Ibáñez. His election took place on February 3, 1997, and he officially joined the Academy on February 22, 1998, after delivering a speech titled "Hipólito" as part of the admission process.

In 1997, Picardo, aged 78, was inducted into the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando, having been nominated by Julio Cano Lasso, Fernando Chueca Goitia, and Luis García-Ochoa Ibáñez. During his admission, he discussed his enthusiasm for architecture and horses, expressing his admiration for the horse's physical prowess and architecture's role in safeguarding and elevating human life.

In 1997, Picardo, aged 78, became a member of the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando, where he shared his admiration for both architecture and horses. He considered them equally perfect, with architecture protecting and enhancing human life, while horses showcased physical prowess. In 2000, Picardo donated his oil painting, Guardia civil en el puerto de Alazores, to the academy, featuring five policemen on five horses.

In 1997, Picardo, at 78, joined the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando, expressing his appreciation for architecture and horses equally. In 2000, he donated his painting, "Guardia civil en el puerto de Alazores," depicting five policemen on horses with different colored legs. The academy also has a 1953 portrait of Picardo, donated by his sons in 2023, which portrays him informally at 34. The academy's collection includes Picardo-related works, like Luis García-Ochoa Ibáñez's portrait, and Picardo's painting, reflecting his admiration for architecture and horses.

In 2001, Picardo received the biannual Premio Antonio Camuñas de Arquitectura, a distinguished accolade acknowledging Spanish architects who have significantly contributed to architectural renovation. The jury commended Picardo, the ninth recipient, for his profound understanding of Spanish culture and his subtle yet impactful professional career, emphasizing his appreciation and reinterpretation of the country's historical architectural heritage. This recognition further highlights Picardo's admiration for architecture, which is also reflected in his painting donated to the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando.

Picardo was married to Trinidad de Ribera Talavera, and they had five children. A US journalist described him in 1972 as an energetic, quick-witted, and imaginative individual with twinkling eyes. He passed away in Madrid on July 27, 2010. This information offers a glimpse into Picardo's personal life, complementing the recognition of his professional achievements in architecture and painting.
